the report. While I agree that a true addiction to porn, as with almost 
anything, can be harmful; but such addictions are definitely exceptions. I 
see nothing here that validates the assumption that this is something 
people shouldn't be enjoying. With many of the kids interviewed, the 
biggest problem was caused by the fact that they felt guilty about it; 
something which can only be attributed to the prevailing, useless negative 
atmosphere surrounding it in the first place.

I might go so far as to say that it is analogous to coffee: just surround 
coffee with an evil atmosphere, say  that kids are too young for it, act 
like people who drink it "too much" have a problem, talk about "getting 
over coffee" as though it were a drug addiction, provide scientific studies 
that prove drinking coffee activates the pleasure/reward centers in your 
brain, and start a movement for tea as a substitute, and there you have it. 
"The Teenage Brain on Coffee"

(interesting note - coffee actually does contain a drug called caffeine, so 
this is a good/bad analogy, depending on how you want to look at it)

but these cases are far outside the realm of what most people experience.
